DataElement.preferredName: In Situ Hybridization DNA Probe Label Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A brief description given for purposes of identification of a piece of DNA that has been labeled, usually radioactively or with a fluorescent dye, which is used in hybridization studies.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues_A piece of DNA that has been labeled, usually radioactively or with a fluorescent dye, which is used in hybridization studies.  Applications include Northern and Southern blots, in situ hybridization techniques, and diagnostic tests.  DNA probes can be highly specific or degenerate.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues

Concepts.definition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues.

Applications include Northern and Southern blots, in situ hybridization techniques, and diagnostic tests.  DNA probes can be highly specific or degenerate.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A brief description given for purposes of identification of a piece of DNA that has been labeled, usually radioactively or with a fluorescent dye, which is used in hybridization studies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Nanometer-sized semiconductor particles, made of cadmium selenide (CdSe), cadmium sulfide (CdS) or cadmium telluride (CdTe) with an inert polymer coating. The semiconductor material used for the core is chosen based upon the emission wavelength range being targeted: CdS for UV-blue, CdSe for the bulk of the visible spectrum, and CdTe for far red and near-infrared. The size of the particle determines the exact color of a given quantum dot. The polymer coating protects cells from cadmium toxicity but also facilitates the attachment of a variety of targeting molecules, including monoclonal antibodies directed to tumor-specific biomarkers. Because of their small size, quantum dots can function as cell- and even molecule-specific markers that will not interfere with the normal cellular functions.

Concepts.definition: Nanometer-sized semiconductor particles, made of cadmium selenide (CdSe), cadmium sulfide (CdS) or cadmium telluride (CdTe) with an inert polymer coating. The semiconductor material used for the core is chosen based upon the emission wavelength range being targeted: CdS for UV-blue, CdSe for the bulk of the visible spectrum, and CdTe for far red and near-infrared. The size of the particle determines the exact color of a given quantum dot. The polymer coating protects cells from cadmium toxicity but also facilitates the attachment of a variety of targeting molecules, including monoclonal antibodies directed to tumor-specific biomarkers. Because of their small size, quantum dots can function as cell- and even molecule-specific markers that will not interfere with the normal cellular functions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of series of proprietary fluorescent dyes that span the visible spectrum. They are typically used as cell and tissue labels in fluorescence microscopy and cell biology.

Concepts.definition: Any of series of proprietary fluorescent dyes that span the visible spectrum. They are typically used as cell and tissue labels in fluorescence microscopy and cell biology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organic compound that has wide use as a synthetic coloring agent. It is prepared by heating phthalic anhydride and resorcinol over a zinc catalyst, and it crystallizes as a deep red powder. This agent emits an intense green fluorescence in the presence of alkaline solutions and therefore is used as a label when conjugated to antibodies or as a contrast agent for ophthalmic angiography.: A chemical group containing the monovalent -N=C=S group. Isothiocyanate is the fundamental structure in many synthetic and biological active compounds.

Concepts.definition: An organic compound that has wide use as a synthetic coloring agent. It is prepared by heating phthalic anhydride and resorcinol over a zinc catalyst, and it crystallizes as a deep red powder. This agent emits an intense green fluorescence in the presence of alkaline solutions and therefore is used as a label when conjugated to antibodies or as a contrast agent for ophthalmic angiography.
A chemical group containing the monovalent -N=C=S group. Isothiocyanate is the fundamental structure in many synthetic and biological active compounds.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Be specific about something; define clearly.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Be specific about something; define clearly.

Applications include Northern and Southern blots, in situ hybridization techniques, and diagnostic tests.  DNA probes can be highly specific or degenerate.:A brief description given for purposes of identification; an identifying or descriptive marker that is attached to an object.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A piece of DNA that has been labeled, usually radioactively or with a fluorescent dye, which is used in hybridization studies.  Applications include Northern and Southern blots, in situ hybridization techniques, and diagnostic tests.  DNA probes can be highly specific or degenerate.
A brief description given for purposes of identification; an identifying or descriptive marker that is attached to an object.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
